> [...] The smell is in the tension between the 
> desired source code layo=

sible for this smell,
> or a JUnit-based solution 
> (like, say, hacking it=
 to use reflection in order to break access 
> control) that doesn't bring =
along serious code smells of its own.

This problem is definitely not a JUn=
it problem.  It is just that it
would be nice if JUnit could handle this pr=
oblem (Works Out of The
Box[1]).

Another tension is that of consistency: i=
f you code ALL your test
classes as Inner classes, you may well use them to=
 test private access
methods also.  If you don't, however, you add an extra=
 smell and
inconsistent use of Inner/Test classes.  This could become a mai=
ntenance
problem.

> I rather liked JB Rainsberger's idea that the need to =
test a private 
> method directly suggests refactoring it into a collaborat=
ing 
> class. I'm not sure it's universally applicable, but i do prefer 
> =
looking for smells in my code rather than my tools.

I also think that extr=
acting some private behaviour into its own class
is a good idea, and a good=
 design decision (at times).  It helps in
maintaining coherence: if a metho=
d doesn't quite fit, move it to another
class.

And although I also prefer =
taking the time going through my code, not
through my tools, sometimes I wo=
uld like to extend my tools with some
features that would help me work even=
 quicker (the reason I have tools
in the first place).  This is why we shar=
e our thoughts with others, to
see if it does seem like a useful feature (d=
epending on votes in
favour).

[May I add:  I actually practice testing pub=
lic (i.e. non-private)
methods, and do not require the private testing func=
tionality.  But I
believe that it should be considered for those who may pr=
efer to code
that way.
